title: 107_s550
content: The Act titled "Indian and Alaska Native Foster Care and Adoption Services Amendments of 2001" allows Indian tribes to receive federal funds for foster care and adoption assistance. Children placed in tribal custody are now eligible for foster care funding under the Social Security Act. This includes Indian tribes or intertribal consortiums that do not operate a program under specific sections, but have agreements with a State or submit arrangements to the Secretary. Children placed in tribal custody are now eligible for foster care funding under the Social Security Act, with arrangements made by Indian tribes or consortiums for the provision of required child welfare services. Indian Tribal Organizations can operate programs under specific sections or have agreements with a State. Children placed in tribal custody are now eligible for foster care funding under the Social Security Act, with arrangements made by Indian tribes or consortiums for the provision of required child welfare services. Indian Tribal Organizations can operate programs under specific sections or have agreements with a State, including programs operated by Indian Tribal Organizations under SEC. 479B. Indian tribes can elect to operate a program under the Social Security Act, with modifications to plan requirements including identifying service areas and approving foster homes. The Indian tribes can elect to operate a program under the Social Security Act, with modifications to plan requirements including identifying service areas and approving foster homes to ensure the safety and accountability of children in foster care. The determination of the federal share is based on the per capita income of the Indian tribe for calculating the Federal medical assistance percentage. The per capita income of an Indian tribe is calculated based on its service population as defined in its plan. The tribe can submit additional relevant information for consideration before the calculation is made. The Secretary determines proportions for Indian tribes' administrative expenditures, ensuring they receive no less than states. Indian tribes can use Federal or State funds to match payments under section 474. The Secretary may modify requirements under this part for Indian tribes if it benefits the safety of children. Participating Indian tribes in a consortium can submit a single plan under section 471. An Indian tribe or intertribal consortium and a State can enter into a cooperative agreement for fund administration under section 471. Any existing cooperative agreements incorporating these provisions remain valid, with the option to modify or revoke them as per the agreement terms. The Secretary will promulgate regulations within 1 year in consultation with Indian tribes and tribal organizations to carry out the agreement terms. Definitions of 'Indian tribe' and 'tribal organization' are as per the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. The amendments made by this section take effect upon enactment of the Act. The amendments made by this section take effect upon enactment of the Act, regardless of regulations being promulgated by that date.
